{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3126441,"name":"","username":"AlexGardiner","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/a/3ec8ea/{size}.png","created_at":"2023-01-14T23:04:49.666Z","cooked":"

Seeing as the official throughbore absolute encoder adaper board is out of stock and absolute encoders are not supported on the alternate encoder adapter board, team 9084 has soldered the throughbore cable to the correct ports on the alternate encoder adapter board to make it report correctly.

Here is how to do it if you have the same issue:
You will be soldering the 5 volt cable (red) from the encoder to port 2 on the spark max data port,
the data cable (white) from the encoder to port 6 on the spark max data port, and
the ground (black) cable from the encoder to port 10 on the spark max data port.

The easiest way to do this is by using the alternate encoder spark max breakout board, or the spark max data port breakout board (We don’t have the data breakout board so we are not sure, it might not work). The ground and the 5 volt contacts are on the top of the board and pin 6 is on the bottom. You need to solder directly to the connecter on the bottom for pin 6. Pin 6 is the port that is directly in the center, on the side with more space. Look at the images below to see examples.

Here is the alternate encoder break board wired correctly:

Here is the pinout for the data port (On the alternate encoder board, there are unused pins on the top and bottom, only the 10 in the middle are actually connected to the spark max):

docs.revrobotics.com

Data Port

It should show up in the rev hardware client correctly when it is done.

Hope this helped anyone with the same problem.

Thanks for this write-up! We were hoping to get the rev through bore encoders but were not quick enough to get them before they went out of stock.

We’ve instead switched to using the SRX mag encoders and yesterday we got them wired and working with our spark maxes using this guide!

For the SRX mag encoders, you should be able to use the traditional ribbon cable they come with. Just remember to cut the relative encoder pins when using them with a NEO.

So can anyone here explain to me the switch on the alternative encoder board that says ABS or Index? When we connect it to a through bore encoders and switch it to ABS, in rev spark max we see the Absolute encoder tab but the readings are all over the place. Is this because of the pin out and the switch is a lie?? We spent several hours today trying to get absolute encoders working with the Alternate encoders board only to find the Absolute encoder board exists and we ordered the wrong thing.

","post_number":4,"post_type":1,"posts_count":9,"updated_at":"2023-02-13T04:04:17.368Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":3,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":5,"reads":213,"readers_count":212,"score":72.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":423187,"topic_slug":"how-to-solder-absolute-rev-throughbore-encoder-to-rev-spark-max-data-port","display_username":"Alex","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":31229,"username":"auscompgeek","name":"Davo","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/auscompgeek/{size}/9867_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":28614,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Mentor & Alumnus"},"post_url":"/t/how-to-solder-absolute-rev-throughbore-encoder-to-rev-spark-max-data-port/423187/4","custom_user_title":"Mentor & Alumnus","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3144563,"name":"Allen Nuttle","username":"nuttle","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/nuttle/{size}/124105_2.png","created_at":"2023-02-13T05:51:59.678Z","cooked":"

This post is worth checking out. Basically, there are numerous permutations – I originally thought you were asking about the switch on the encoder itself, which is (sort of) another variable.

This is an issue with encoders in FRC generally – you have to be careful how you hook these up, and there are many different adaptors, breakout boards, etc. There are cases where the same connectors are used but the pin outs are incompatible.

Offhand, I don’t know of a use case for that switch being in the ABS position, since the PWM input is on pin 6 (the switch is for pin 4). At the time this older board was designed, I don’t think PWM absolute input was implemented. To be clear, I can’t/don’t speak for REV and this bit of history is mostly just speculation on my part.

Ya, we saw both of those while troubleshooting and we eventually came to the conclusion that it wasn’t possible and the switch is a lie. The whole thing is just somewhat confusing since things seem to be contradictory.

we were able to get our through bore reading absolute last night after roughly 2 days of trying things, we did this without any breakout board currently however we just ordered the absolute encoder adapter which will just make our birds nest easier to manage, if you are still struggling I can send you our wiring diagram.
